text.p: ** BIRTHDAYS **
American novelist LOUISA M. ALCOTT, best-remembered for "Little Women", was born in 1832. Her novel has been turned into a film many times, the latest in 1995.
Melbourne industrialist, JABEZ GADSDEN, who produced Australia's first printed tin can - a Queen Victoria jubilee tea caddy - was born in 1858.
Irish scholar and writer C.S.LEWIS, who wrote the popular children's book series set in the land of Narnia, was born in 1898.
American songwriter and record producer BERRY GORDY, who founded the first all-black record company, was born in 1929.
South Australian winemaker and yachtsman SIR JAMES GILBERT HARDY was born in 1932.
American singer JODY MILLER, who had a big hit in 1965 with "Queen of the Road", was born in 1941.
** EVENTS **
1641 : The first English newspaper was published.
1864 : At least 150 Indian warriors, women and children

were killed in a Massacre at Sand Creek in Colorado. The killing was carried out by 750 US cavalry under the Command of Colonel JOHN M. CHIVINGTON. The Cheyene and Arapho warriors and their families had surrendered after three years of war and after being disarmed they were sent to Sand Creek. They were defenseless against the attack.
1922 : The New South Wales government passed a lead

poisoning compensation Bill which would enable work to resume in six Broken Hill mines. The mines were closed for 3-1/-2 years after industrial action. The Inquiry into the dispute ruled they could not be worked on a 44-hour week basis until compensation conditions were established.
1943 : The first summit conference between Russia's
JOSEPH STALIN, US leader FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT and Britain's WINSTON CHURCHILL began in Tehran. The Allied leaders discussed the progress of the war and planned for the future.
1945 : The Federal government revealed that 27,273
Australian servicemen and women lost their lives in World War II. More than 16,000 were killed in action and another 23,500 were wounded.
1954 : ROBERT MENZIES became Australia's longest serving
Prime Minister passing BILLY HUGHES' record of 7 years 105 days.
1965 : In Britain, housewife MARY WHITEHOUSE announced
the formation of the national Viewers' and Listeners' Association as a watchdog body to stop sex, violence and bad taste on the BBC.
1968 : Five people died and 130 were injured in bush
fires in the Blue Mountains west of Sydney.
1971 : The British government announced a fund of five
and a half million dollars for thalidomide victims.
1982 : THOMAS KENEALLY became the first Australian to win
the Booker Prize with "Schindler's Ark", which detailed the plight of Jews in Nazi Germany. The book formed the basis of the 1993 award-winning STEVEN SPIELBERG movie "Schindler's List".
1985 : British cricketer IAN BOTHAM completed a charity
walk for leukaemia research from John O'Groats to Land's End.
1989 : Romanian gymnast and Olympic gold medal-winner
NADIA COMANECI escaped to Hungary and asked for political asylum.
1990 : Germany began airlifts of food to Moscow.
1994 : American serial killer JEFFREY DAHMER was murdered
in prison, where he was serving multiple life sentences for the killings of 17 young men and boys.
